docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: MeshtasticÂ® is a project that enables you to use inexpensive LoRa radios as a long range off-grid communication platform in areas without existing or reliable communications infrastructure. This project is 100% community driven and open source!

docs.title: Meshtastic Encryption
docs.description: Cryptography is tricky, so we've tried to 'simply' apply standard crypto solutions to our implementation. However, the project developers are not cryptography experts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: How it works

docs.title: Mesh Broadcast Algorithm
docs.description: Current Algorithm

docs.title: Radio Settings
docs.description: Meshtastic is not LoRaWAN, Helium or TTN (TheThingsNetwork). Meshtastic uses the full spectrum frequency range designated to LoRa technology per region. This allows for several hundred possible frequency channels in the US region alone.

docs.title: Range Tests
docs.description: <Tabs

docs.title: Ambient Lighting Module Usage
docs.description: The Ambient Lighting Module has settings for control of onboard LEDs and allows users to adjust the brightness levels and respective color levels. Initially created for the RAK14001 RGB LED module using the NCP5623 with I2C. Config options are: LED State, Current, Red Level, Green Level, and Blue Level.

docs.title: Audio Module Configuration
docs.description: The audio module config options are: Codec2 Enabled, PTT GPIO, Audio Bitrate/Codec Mode, I2S Word Select, I2S Data IN, I2S Data OUT and I2S Clock. Audio Module config uses an admin message sending a ConfigModule.Audio protobuf.

docs.title: Canned Message Module Configuration
docs.description: The Canned Message Module will allow you to send messages to the mesh network from the device without using the phone app. You can predefine text messages to choose from.

docs.title: Detection Sensor Module Usage
docs.description: The Detection Sensor module allows you to configure a GPIO pin to be monitored for a specified high/low status and send text alerts over the  Detection Sensor portnum when an event is detected. This is particularly useful for motion detection sensors, reed switches, and other open / closed state systems in which notifications over the mesh are desired.  Config options are: Enabled, Minimum Broadcast Interval, State Broadcast Interval, Send Bell, Name, Monitor Pin, Detection Triggered High, and Use Pull-up.

docs.title: External Notification Module Configuration
docs.description: The External Notification Module will allow you to connect a buzzer, speaker, LED, or other device to notify you when a message has been received from the mesh network. You can enable up to 3 pins independently from each other.

docs.title: Module Configuration
docs.description: Modules are included in the firmware and allow users to extend the functionality of their mesh or device.

docs.title: MQTT Module Configuration
docs.description: If your device is connected to Internet via wifi or ethernet, you can enable it to forward packets along to an MQTT server. This allows users on the local mesh to communicate with users on the internet. One or more channels must also be enabled as uplink and/or downlink for packets to be transmitted from and/or to your mesh (See channels). Without these settings enabled, the node will still connect to the MQTT server but only send status messages.

docs.title: Neighbor Info Module Usage
docs.description: The Neighbor Info Module is for sending information on each node's 0-hop neighbors to the mesh. Config options are: Enabled and Update Interval.

docs.title: Range Test Module Configuration
docs.description: This module allows you to test the range of your Meshtastic nodes. It requires at least two nodes, a sender and a receiver. The receiving node saves the messages along with the GPS coordinates at which they were received into a .csv file. This .csv file can then be integrated into Google Earth, Google Maps - My Maps, or any other program capable of processing .csv files. This can enable you to visualize your mesh.

docs.title: Remote Hardware Module Usage
docs.description: The Remote Hardware Module allows control of a GPIO pin on a remote node. Config options are: Enabled, Allow Undefined Pin Access, Available Pins

docs.title: Serial Module Configuration
docs.description: The serial module config options are: Enabled, Echo, Mode, Receive GPIO, Transmit GPIO, Baud Rate, Timeout, and Override Console Serial Port. Serial Module config uses an admin message sending a ConfigModule.Serial protobuf.

docs.title: Store & Forward Module Settings
docs.description: Currently only available for ESP32 based devices with external PSRAM like the tbeam. Requires the device to be set as a ROUTER or ROUTER_CLIENT.

docs.title: Telemetry Module Configuration
docs.description: The Telemetry Module provides three types of data over the mesh: Device metrics (Battery Level, Voltage, Channel Utilization and Airtime) from your Meshtastic device, Environment Metrics from attached I2C sensors, and Air Quality Metrics from attached I2C particle sensors.

docs.title: Traceroute Module Usage
docs.description: Due to the limited bandwidth of LoRa, Meshtastic does not keep track of the nodes a message used to hop to the destination. However, from firmware 2.0.8 on, there is a Traceroute Module that can show you this.

docs.title: Bluetooth Settings
docs.description: The Bluetooth config options are: Enabled, Pairing Mode and Fixed PIN Value. Bluetooth config uses an admin message sending a Config.Bluetooth protobuf.

docs.title: Channel Configuration
docs.description: The Channels config options are: Index, Roles, and Settings. Channel config uses an admin message sending a Channel protobuf which also consists of a ChannelSettings protobuf.

docs.title: Radio Configuration
docs.description: There are several config sections in the Meshtastic firmware, these are broken out so they can be sent as small admin messages over the mesh.

docs.title: Device Configuration
docs.description: The device config options are: Role, Serial Output, and Debug Log. Device config uses an admin message sending a Config.Device protobuf.

docs.title: Display Configuration
docs.description: The display config options are: Screen On Duration, Auto Carousel Interval, Always Point North, GPS Format, Preferred Display Units, OLED Definition, Display Mode, Heading Bold, and Wake on Tap or Motion. Display config uses an admin message sending a Config.Display protobuf.

docs.title: LoRa Configuration
docs.description: The LoRa config options are: Region, Modem Preset, Max Hops, Transmit Power, Bandwidth, Spread Factor, Coding Rate, Frequency Offset, Transmit Enabled, Channel Number, Ignore Incoming Array, Override Duty Cycle Limit, SX126x RX Boosted Gain, and Override Frequency. LoRa config uses an admin message sending a Config.LoRa protobuf.

docs.title: Network Configuration
docs.description: The Network config options are: NTP Server, WiFi Enabled, WiFi SSID, WiFi PSK, Ethernet Enabled, IPv4 Networking Mode, and Static Address. Network config uses an admin message sending a Config.Network protobuf.

docs.title: Position Configuration
docs.description: The position config options are: GPS Enabled, GPS Update Interval, GPS Attempt Time, Fixed Position, Smart Broadcast, Smart Broadcast Minimum Distance, Smart Broadcast Minimum Interval, Broadcast Interval, Position Packet Flags, and GPS RX/TX Pins. Position config uses an admin message sending a Config.Position protobuf.

docs.title: Power Configuration
docs.description: Power settings are advanced configuration, most users should choose a role under Device Config to manage power for their device and shouldn't ever need to adjust these settings.

docs.title: User Configuration
docs.description: The user config options are: Long Name, Short Name, and Is Licensed. User config uses an admin message sending a User protobuf.

docs.title: Remote Node Administration
docs.description: This is an advanced feature that few users should need. Keep in mind that it is possible (if you are not careful) to assign settings to a remote node that cause it to completely drop off of your mesh. We advise network admins have a test node to test settings with before applying changes to a remote node to prevent this.

docs.title: Client API (Serial/TCP/BLE)
docs.description: This document describes the protocol for external API clients using our devices. If you are interested in running your own code on the device itself, see the module API documentation instead.

docs.title: Critical Error Codes
docs.description: The device might report these fault codes on the screen, but it will also be outputted on the device serial output. If you encounter a fault code, please post on the forum and we'll try to help.

docs.title: HTTP API
docs.description: This is a mini-spec on a HTTP API which can be used by browser based clients to interact with Meshtastic devices.

docs.title: Module API
docs.description: The purpose of this tutorial is for writing new core modules that can be run on a device. In most cases, it is best to start with utilizing the serial module rather than creating a new one. However, if you're interested in creating a new core functionality from scratch, then building a module would be appropriate.

docs.title: Maintaining Documentation
docs.description: Meshtastic documentation is an important ingredient to the overall project. We want users to hit the ground running with the information they need right at their finger tips. This section will discuss the documentation software stack, file organization, and style guides.

docs.title: Flash nRF52 Factory Erase
docs.description: Meshtastic uses the littlefs library to store configuration, logs, and other data in the internal flash of nRF52 devices. Updating the firmware does not erase this additional data, which can cause issues when the format and location of data changes between releases.

docs.title: nRF52 OTA Firmware Updates
docs.description: nRF52 devices from RAK are able to accept OTA firmware updates from a mobile device over bluetooth. The T-Echo bootloader does not have OTA support.

docs.title: Antenna Testing
docs.description: Testing of antennas can be both simple and complex. At its simplest, testing involves sending messages from different locations and seeing which ones are received, and then comparing the results against other antennas. At the complex end, this can be using expensive test chambers and equipment to measure the signal strength, gain, and radiation patterns. However, it seems that a reasonable job can be done with cheaper methods.

docs.title: LoRa Antenna Selection
docs.description: The stock antennas provided with the T-Beam and other boards usually come from 'mixed bags'. They may not have been designed or tuned for your given frequency range, and they may not be of a quality design.

They are designed to strike a balance between RF performance, size, ruggedness, and power efficiency â providing users with a reliable solution in various outdoor environments.

docs.title: LILYGOÂ® TTGO T-Beam Devices
docs.description: All T-beam models (with the exception of the S3-Core) have an 18650 size battery holder on the rear of the device. This is designed to the original specification of the 18650 and only fits unprotected flat top 18650 cells. Button top and protected cells are typically longer than 65mm, often approaching 70mm.

docs.title: Licensing & Commercial Projects Usage
docs.description: You are hereby granted a two-year non-exclusive license to use the MeshtasticÂ® logo and trademark on your product/project provided you adhere to the trademark guidelines. No fee is required for this usage, though if you wish keeping $1/unit set-aside so that it can eventually fund Meshtastic it would be appreciated.

docs.title: Meshtastic privacy policy
docs.description: We don't collect any personal identifying information. We never capture usernames, the contents of your texts, or your location data.

docs.title: Trademark Rules & Brand Guidelines
docs.description: MeshtasticÂ® is a registered trademark of Meshtastic LLC. Meshtastic software components are released under various licenses, see GitHub for details. No warranty is provided - use at your own risk.

docs.title: Meshtastic Python CLI installation
docs.description: This library provides a command line interface (CLI) for managing the user settings of Meshtastic nodes and provides an easy API for sending and receiving messages over mesh radios. Events are delivered using a publish-subscribe model, and you can subscribe to only the message types you are interested in.

docs.title: Meshtastic Python CLI Guide
docs.description: The python pip package installs a "meshtastic" command line executable, which displays packets sent over the network as JSON and lets you see serial debugging information from the meshtastic devices. This command is not run inside of python, you run it from your operating system shell prompt directly. If when you type "meshtastic" it doesn't find the command and you are using Windows: Check that the python "scripts" directory is in your path.

docs.title: Using the Meshtastic CLI
docs.description: This section covers using the "meshtastic" command line executable, which displays packets sent over the network as JSON and lets you see serial debugging information from the Meshtastic devices.
